awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transformative Approaches to Achieving Very High Density Cryogenic Sensor Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Transformative Approaches to Achieving Very High Density Cryogenic Sensor Arrays

Joseph C. Bardin, University of Massachusetts Amherst

Intellectual Merit: Low-temperature superconductor based sensing systems offer unprecedented sensitivity, but compared to their room temperature counterparts, are relatively undeveloped. The research objective of this program is to explore how the information gathering capabilities of cryogenic sensor systems can be improved by an order of magnitude through novel combinations of ultra-low-power silicon circuits and superconducting sensors. Two different system applications will be studied: terahertz superconductor-insulator-superconductor mixer focal plane arrays and near-infrared superconducting nanowire single photon detector cameras. In each case, the quantitative goal will be to enable the realization of cameras with over 1,000 independent pixels in a single 4 K cryostat. Achieving this level of integration will require an order of magnitude reduction in the power consumption of the active electronics. The basic research carried out under this program is expected to advance the state of the art in cryogenic integrated circuit design, ultra-low-power cryogenic low-noise amplifiers, superconducting nanowire single photon detector readout, on-wafer noise measurement techniques, and the heterogeneous integration of superconductor and semiconductor circuits. This research is important because it addresses open problems in measurement, design, and system integration, and the resulting system capabilities will be transformative to members of the scientific community.

Broader Impacts: The most sensitive of experimental systems rely upon cryogenically cooled electronics. These systems allow scientists to push measurements towards the limits of fundamental physics, and thus have had a profound impact on experimental science. For instance, cryogenically cooled electronic systems allow scientists to study basic physical phenomena through low-temperature physics experiments, to communicate with spacecraft at distant planets, to interface to quantum computers, and to probe the history and contents of the universe through radio astronomy. If successful, the improved instruments that will be enabled by this research program will greatly expand the toolset that scientists have to gather data. The broader impacts also include an aggressive educational and outreach program, which targets participants at all levels. The research themes of the program will be leveraged in order to improve course offerings, both at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and a set of seminars aimed at high school teachers will be created and offered through the UMass STEMEd program.  Finally, low-temperature electronics is a field in which there is limited expertise, and the training of new experts who understand the applications of these systems will help to ensure that forward progress continues in the years to come. To this end, a set of yearly scientific site visits will be organized in which graduate and undergraduate researchers will have the opportunity to present their research results to leading scientists and to learn about ongoing work at some of the nations premier research institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to explore the use of low-temperature silicon germanium integrated circuits to enhance the information gathering capabilities of cryogenically cooled scientific instrumentation. Two target systems were identified: THz heterodyne focal plane arrays and superconducting nanowire single photon detectors.  These applications have significnatly different requirements and were selected to allow for the exploration of a wide range of circuits. 

THz heterodyne instruments are used to study planetary and star formation through the observation of molecular lines in the THz frequency regime. At THz frequencies, limited receiver sensitivity resulting from atmospheric absorption means that acquiring a single pixel of an image requires significant integration. To compensate for long integration times, one would like to use a camera, so as to parallelize the image acquisition process. However, whereas optical astronomy is carried out with mega-pixel-scale cameras, the heterodyne cameras available at THz frequencies are much more limited in scale, with the largest reported to date being a 64-pixel system. A roadblock to increasing the scale of these systems is that they must be cooled to a physical temperature of 4 K and each pixel requires a semiconductor low noise amplifier (LNA) which is thermalized to this temperature. Since the power handling of the most powerful 4-K closed-cycle refrigeration system is just 1.5 W  and available amplifiers dissipate 5-10 mW, implementing systems with more than about 100 pixels will require reducing the power consumption of the cryogenic LNAs. Our goal was to develop techniques to reduce the power consumption of cryogenic LNAs to 375 uW, which would enable the implementation of a 1000 pixel dual-polarization THz heterodyne camera. 

Our hypothesis was that we could reduce the power consumption of cryogenic LNAs by a factor of 10x while preserving other performance metrics using SiGe heterojunction bipolar transistors (HBTs) operating in the weakly saturated regime (i.e., with low supply voltages). To study this approach, we first developed a new theory that enables descibing the noise properties of a SiGe HBT continuosouly through various modes of operation. Armed with this model, we then analyzed the cryogenic performance of a commercial SiGe technology versus dissipation and found that we could achieve near nominal noise performance while reducing the power consumption by 5x, just by operating at low supply voltages. We then designed at tested a proof of concept amplifier that dissipated just 300uW. Having demonstrated our basic concept, we worked with the Harvard Smithsonian CFA to demonstrate a series of integrated THz receivers using this technology. In the end, we built a complete THz pixel which operated with just 300uW of power consumption while providing competitive performance in comparison to a standard 10mW pixel. So, we not only demonstrated that it is possible to reduce the power consumption of cryogenic LNAs by 10x, we also used our technology in a practical THz receiver. This research produced a total of 3 journal papers, 4 conference papers, one plenary, and one best student paper competition award (ASC, 2016).

Superconducting nanowire single photon detectors (SNSPDs) are among the highest performance single photon detectors. These devices are essential in a variety of emerging applications including quantum communications, photonic quantum computing, and deep-space communications. However, the way in which they are typically operated leads to a tradeoff between system efficiency and count rates. Our hypothesis was that an active SiGe controller circuit could be used with a  SNSPD to overcome the tradeoff between system efficiency and recovery time. To test this hypothesis, we first developed models that allowed for the cosimulation of a SNSPD and the SiGe controller circuit. We then developed a circuit to control the dynamics of a SNSPD, enabling a faster reset than is achievable using standard approaches. The integrated circuit was fabricated and the performance of the SNSPD/SiGe system was measured in the lab. In comparison to the standard configuration, we found that our new approach permitted a speedup of nearly 2x, meaning that a single SNSPD controlled using our approach could be used to receive 2x the data in comparison to one using the standard approach. We also found that the timing jitter was improved with our approach. This work produced a total of three invited talks and one journal paper. 

This CAREER project provided opportunities for many students. One PhD student has already received her degree and a second student (supported towards the end of their degree) will be defending in the upcoming months. Four REU students were supported by the project and, of these students, three have gone on to pursue graduate degrees at prestegious universities (e.g., CU Boulder and Caltech). Finally, the PI organized a pair of scientific site visits at NRAO and NIST Boulder, where a large group of students were able to tour these first-rate scientific laboratories and interact with professional scientists.
